episode.title: Local Lodge No. 1424, International Association of Machinists, AFL-CIO, v. National Labor Relations Board

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Come, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: May it please the Court.
As I started to point out at the -- at the recess, the kind of situation that you had here -- well, you had the continuing application in the union security clause going on.
We kept the dispute, as the court below pointed out, rankling at least once a month in the mind of the employees, and the record bears this out.
It shows that an error of uncertainty prevailed among the employees as to how the Union got in when they learned of the union security agreement.
Their inquiries met evasive replies and accusations of being troublemakers.
Now, what --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What are you quoting from now?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I'm quoting from the -- my --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I just want to read it if it is in the record.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think that the findings of the Board, as set forth in -- in our brief, bear out -- I'm paraphrasing, Your Honor, “However, the continued application of the contract kept the employees wondering and toward the end of the first year of the contract when it became appropriate to reopen it, the questioning resumed and at this time, the IAM representative explained to a group of the employees that the Union had gotten in because it had the company connected with Bryan over a barrel.”
This is at Record Reference 101.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The IAM representative explained to the employees, as late as the summer of 1955, about 10 months after the contract had run when they were continuing to wonder why it is that they -- that the IAM had -- had gotten this contract.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Who passed the barrel?
Well, I --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That the Union had gotten in, this is the IAM representative explaining to the employees because it had a company connected with Bryan, the petitioner here, over a barrel.
In other words, the contract with the Union and Bryan was part of the quid pro quo for settling some other dispute that the Union had with another related employer.
And shortly, thereafter, the charges here were filed.
So you didn't have something that -- that died down right at the outset.

And, we submit, the realities of industrial life are such that, in a matter of this sort, you do not end with the execution of the contract, particularly where, as I pointed out earlier, you have new employees that are being added here throughout the period.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who was the witness who testified there?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I believe it was one of the employees, Your Honor.
That's at Record 101, testifying as to what the union organizer, Mr. Schwartzmiller, had told him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is this Local 701 of the CIO?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: This is Local 1424 of -- it was -- I didn't get your question.
Was the witness --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean to say --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- a member of --Did the CIO have -- have a contract any time during its term?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

This is the Machinists representative, Local Lodge 1424, the petitioner here, explaining to one of the employees at the plant as to how it was that this Union got into the plant and got a contract which compel the employee to join the Union.
The Board credited this testimony.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When was that given?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That was given in June of 1955, after the contract had run about 10 months, Your Honor, the -- the initial contract.
So, we have here a situation --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what there -- by that, do you mean that he said they had them over a barrel and -- and they forced him to do it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The reason I -- reason I ask that is because the next question was what -- was anything else said?
Answer -- “Was anything said by anyone else on that?”
Answer, “Well, general conversation.”
Question, “What was that general conversation?”
“They wanted to crept to -- they wanted to get it across that they came in legal.”
That's what they were trying to get across to us.

Apparently, not that they had not gotten them over a barrel and coerced them into do it, but -- doing it but, apparently, that they -- there were some relationship that made it legal for them to do this.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, the inference, Your Honor, that the Board draws from this testimony and from the related testimony of the other witnesses was that the union organizers made no secret about the fact that they got in not because they had organized the employees but because the employer had given them a contract.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, that's not disputed, is it not?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, that is not disputed.
The Union is not denying here or disputing, as I understand it, the findings of the Board that it did not have a majority at the time the contract was -- was entered into.
I just wanted to indicate that the employees continued to have some question about this, long after the contract was -- was executed.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Does that bear on the issue you've got?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I think it bears on -- on the issue in the sense that the argument is made that the statute of limitations are intended to -- to give repose.

And our answer to that is that, that is true in a situation where the conduct has stopped but where you have a continuing enforcement of the contract, as you had here, you continue to dispute and it rankled -- it bothered the employees each month, and I was just pointing out that that fact which you could reasonably expect would happen was indeed borne out by the -- by the record here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, you want -- I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You have that same -- you could make that same argument in the (Inaudible) where there's no union security clause involved.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think you could, Your Honor, but you'd have greater difficulty in -- in proving that that was sought.

I think that where you have something as affirmative as a continuing collection of dues, you are taking some positive steps within the period to continue the wrong that was perpetrated at the -- at the outset.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Supposing the Union, during this period, had been complaisant about the -- the security fee, it accepted the fee and voluntarily paid a followup -- followup on those who pay, what would your situation be like?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I think that we might get close to those company union cases that Mr. Dunau has -- has cited.

It might make a difference where there was no -- where the situation remained passive within the period, but that is not this case and I think that, in this case, we have some very positive acts that were occurring which are clearly -- would amount to additional unfair labor practices but for the 10 (b) problem here.
And we submit that that is no barrier here because we looked at the past events merely for shedding light on what occurred here.

In other words, what I'm trying to say is that whatever may be said of the situation you present, Mr. Justice Harlan, it's pretty well settled, at least in the Courts of Appeals, that you have separate unfair labor practices not only when you enforce an illegal union security clause.
You've got an unfair labor practice at the time of the execution and you have got it when you -- when you enforce it.

The Second Circuit, I think, made that clear in the Gaynor News case which is a little bit closer to the situation that we have here than the illegal on its face cases that I mentioned at the -- at the outset.

In the Gaynor News case, you had a union security clause that was illegal not because of anything that appeared from the face of the contract, I mean, the clause there provided for becoming a union member within 45 days is permitted by 8 (a) (3), but the clause was illegal because, at the time the contract was entered into, there had not been a union shop election as required by Section 9 (e) of the Act.
So, it was necessary to leave the face of the contract for the purpose of ascertaining whether this past event had occurred.
And the Board found and the Second Circuit in an opinion by Judge Frank upheld the Board's finding that 10 (b) was not barred here.

Whatever may be said about the execution of the contract, the maintenance of that illegal contract within the limitations period, notwithstanding the fact that you had to leave the face of the contract to determine its illegality, was a separate unfair labor practice as to which, as Judge Frank put it, the limitations period had not yet begun to run.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, are you arguing, in effect, that through the active enforcement of the 1954 agreement within the statutory period, the 1954 agreement has made a continuing unfair labor practice just as an innocent overt act may continue a conspiracy to demand people in jail or the conspiracy itself has been outlawed and nothing remains except this innocent overt act which pose the agreement into the requisite statutory period?
Is that what you're arguing?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think that my argument comes close to that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, it's a very different thing from saying that the original illegality is a continuing illegality and saying that an isolated act within the statutory period is a new unfair labor practice.
They are different things.
It may come to the same result but I think the analyses are different.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Come, let me ask you this.

Suppose this charge had not been brought when it was and toward the end of this three-year agreement that they had, the parties entered into another agreement for five years, based upon the same relationship, and nothing was done there until toward the end of the five years of the next contract.
Could they date that back to -- to this unfair labor practice that you are talking about and -- and avoid those situations then?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think that the logic of the -- of the Board's position, assuming that the contract continued to be enforced --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- would permit that.
However, we have running across that however.

The concurrent principle of the weight and relevancy of -- to be given to -- to ancient evidence in a situation such as that, it might be extremely difficult for the Board to obtain any probative evidence that could establish the original illegality.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's true.
Well, these don't -- these don't bother about how difficult it would be.
Would -- would the Board have the power to do that in the light of this Section 10 (b)?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think it would, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Your answer, if I understand, is upon the maintenance of a relationship --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- not the making of a contract so you can go except the record you (Inaudible) what is done yet to be (Inaudible) it may be legally justified by it, is that it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We are not predicating any liability on the original making of the contract.
We are looking to the events surrounding that and it's not necessary for us to determine that that is an unfair labor practice.

It's -- it happens to be accidental that those past events would to add up to an independent unfair labor practice of their own, but that is irrelevant to the use which the -- which the Board puts the facts that it gathers from the past period.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Why do you look to it (Inaudible) at all?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, we look to the making of the contract to see whether or not, within the current period, the Union has available to it the defense that it is privilege to exact these dues payments because it was the majority -- it is the majority representative.

The collection of -- of dues and the requiring of employees to join a union as a condition of employment is the clearest form of violation of the Act and had we had nothing more than that and this contract were -- were not in the picture, there'd be no question that there'd be an unfair labor practice.
Now, the company comes forward with the -- with the contract.

At that point, the question is whether the contract really affords them a defense, and the Board is going to the past period there to ascertain whether or not the defense of majority status is available to the Union with respect to the acts that it's performing currently.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything in the Act, aside from 10 (b), that would provide for any repose, any lack of -- any -- any time at all within a period of years which would make the contract not subject to attack if it would had originally a -- some defect in it, nobody raised it and it was renewed and renewed from time to time for 10 years? Is there anything in the statute?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I do not think that there is, other than the difficulties of proof that you would have.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I suppose you -- if it -- like you do now, you'd look back to this first time am I -- employees might have going along for years.
If you ask what year, it's been almost a year, and you just look back to see what happened the first time, then there is no statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: There is a statute of limitations with respect to a conduct that has -- that has seized.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As I understand it, here, you will seize it if they have a contract and then renewed a contract and renewed a contract and renewed a contract.
It's still going on.
That's right, isn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is right, Your Honor.
The original dispute is being continued currently.
It's the -- it's the nature of this particular controversy.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think the Court, under circumstances like that, they might -- I expected you to give another answer, maybe it's -- maybe it wouldn't be a good answer, the courts is just acting somewhat in the equitable capacity to hold that it's barred by laches?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, it's been held that laches does not apply to the Government in particularly, the Board proceedings.
However, the Board itself, prior to the enactment of 10 (b), did have a laches principle which it invoked on its own.
If it found that an employee, for example, was unduly delayed in -- in filing a charge of a wrongful discharge, it would toll the running of -- of back pay.
And I think that it is within the Board's discretion and power to do that even apart from -- from 10 (b).
Now, I'd like to talk --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- from -- before we get to that?
Is there any other case prior to this one in which the Board has delineated this policy that you might refer us to or is this the first time that -- that they have done it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, the -- as I -- as I think I indicated earlier, this continuing violation theory is not a new one.
That has been applied in a number of -- of illegal union security cases, all of which are mentioned in our brief, in situations where the agreement was invalid on its face --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: On its face.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- or in the Gaynor case were not on its face but because of some condition that they didn't satisfy with respect to getting a union authorization election.
This is the first case where the infirmity in the contract is of the type that -- that we have here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I believe valid on its face.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Valid on its face, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Come, what was the (Inaudible) and you drew as pertinent to this contract, and they do it defensively to show the justification for what's done today.
Is that right or is it you, the Board, who relies on the contracts?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I think, analytically, it is probably the company and the Union that do but as soon as the contract comes to light, the burden is then shifted to the -- to the Board to establish the validity of the contract.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Or the invalidity.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Or the invalidity of it.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But until the contract is asserted defensively and the justification which they conduct, there is no such issue, isn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think, analytically, that is right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In fact, it broadened it.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, as a -- as a practical matter, the Board, in investigating these cases, is going to try to anticipate possible defenses, and they're going to look to see whether or not there is a contract in the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they knew that, didn't they?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: What's that?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When they started out, they knew there was a contract.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Wanted a way to find it's invalid or to do something on it.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: But I think, analytically, it is correct that the contract is a -- is a defense because if you did not have the contract in the picture and you had only the allegation that the employees were being compelled to join a union and pay dues on its face, there, you -- you have, unquestionably, a -- a prima facie violation of the Act.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: By the way, do you have now, without waiting for the memorandum, the cases where the company applied this rule, where the Board applies this rule in company union cases?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I do not have them.
Mr. Dunau has cited some in his brief, and I was going to supply some additional --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you mean it supports your view point?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, “dissupport” his view point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, when -- don't you have any cited that supports yours in what the Board had done before in company union cases?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I -- I have them to support my position in what the Board has done in other situations where they have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I know.
What company union situations?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The one -- I have one company union case, namely, Superior Engraving, which is cited in our brief.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's -- what's the name?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Superior Engraving.
That is a Seventh Circuit opinion, Mr. Justice Black, which is 183 F.2d 783.
In that case, I might indicate, the situation was this.
You had a refusal to bargain and unilateral wage increases within the limitations period.
At the time this occurred, the Union did not have -- did not represent a majority of the employees.
Therefore, the employer's action --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What union was that?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: What's that?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What union was that?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I don't remember --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it a regular --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- the union.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- or a company?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, it was not a company union.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It was not a company union.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It was a regular union.
Therefore, the employer's action was unlawful only if the loss of majority were attributable to prior unfair labor practices.

Now, in that case, it was held that Section 10 (b) did not bar evidence that the employer had engaged in 8 (a) (2) activity with respect to another union which had the effect of dissipating the majority of the outside union within the limitations period.
And the Board's finding of a refusal to bargain was sustained by the -- by the Seventh Circuit.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was that as part of the evidence?
Did they base it, the holding, at all on the unfair -- on the unfair labor practice at the beginning?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, it was based solely on that because all that you had within the limitations period were actions which, standing alone, did not give you an unfair labor practice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about standing alone.
What -- you had actions if -- that the Board put its holding on them.
They didn't put it in part on -- or did it, put it in part on the original making of the -- of the original one that was barred?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The original one that was -- that was barred, the assistance to the company union was the basis for finding that the loss of majority of the independent union within the period --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean they used that as evidence from which to infer that later on, it was wrong.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Constitute an unfair labor practice.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In -- in your brief, Mr. Come, did you respond to the citations that Mr. Dunau had in his brief one of these company unions?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I don't think that we did, Your Honor, because we regarded the situation there as being distinguishable in view of the fact that you did not, in those cases, have any of the affirmative action that you had in -- in this case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you didn't distinguish them for us in your brief.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, Your Honor.I intend to do that in this memorandum that I have leave to follow.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You had his brief before you wrote yours?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, we did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you go -- you mean going to write a brief now for us?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, Your --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't that --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, no, Your Honor, I am not.
As --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I must ask for the cases.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: As -- as I understand it, that is right, and Mr. Justice Frankfurter requested, and I understood that that was to be included, that I comment upon Mr. Dunau's cases.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you this.
Quite -- what do you do with the legislative history, more particularly, the -- the reference to the rider in Senate Report 105?
And I ask that because the Board, in construing this -- in dealing with this problem and recognizing the novelty of it, as they did in terms, don't seem to discuss the legislative history problem.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I was just coming to that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Good.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: We have discussed it in our brief however.
We believe that the riders had a broader sweep than 10 (b).

In the first place, the language of the original rider which was introduced in 1944 provided in relevant part that no funds shall be used in any way in connection with a complaint arising over an agreement between management and labor which has been in existence for three months or longer without a complaint being filed.
This language would have precluded using the agreement for any purposes.
You couldn't predicate a violation on the contract even if it were invalid on its face, a situation which petitioners concede would not be barred by Section 10 (b).

And I think the reason for that is that, and this is borne out by the legislative history of the -- of the riders, that the purpose that Congress had there was a broader purpose than they had with respect to 10 (b).

They weren't concerned solely with protecting against stale claims rather, the riders were designed to prevent interruptions to war production through a tax by outside unions on closed-shop contracts that had been entered into in the -- in the defense industries and -- and the shipyards where the necessary production was being gotten out and the employees immediately involved weren't complaining about the illegality of the contract.
In other words, it was aimed at preventing disruption to wartime production.
What this wartime objective, Congress could well have continence and, we in -- as we think the language of the riders shows, more of an invasion on the statutory rights of the employees.
Then, it was going to permit in 1947 when it came around to enacting a limitations provision as such.
And therefore, we think that when Congress said in the Senate Report that the riders were unnecessary because they were now enacting a limitations provision.

This was merely a generalized statement to the effect that, since they were dealing with questions of liability for past unfair labor practices, specifically in 10 (b), the rider was no longer needed without necessarily suggesting that the scope of the rider was the same as that of 10 (b) which, from the reading that I have given to this Court, it is apparent that it is not.

Moreover, it is very interesting that by the time Congress got around to enacting 10 (b), the rider had -- had been so watered down that in fact, it would even have had less scope than 10 (b) has even under the Board's interpretation because in the years subsequent to 1944, when it was first enacted, they excluded contracts with company-dominated unions.
In other words, the three-month bar didn't -- didn't apply to that kind of a contract.
They excluded renewals of an -- this is from the riders, renewals of an existing contract on the three-month limitation.
And then the very same Congress which enacted 10 (b), despite the fact that they said that the rider wasn't necessary, goes ahead and nevertheless enacts a rider for 1948.
And in that rider, they give immunity only to contracts with a majority union, and the reason they say that is that they didn't want to sanction these sweetheart arrangements.
But a contract is entered into when the union does not represent a minority.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think that repealed Section 10 (b) if it doesn't accept the application and the report indicating it has -- should have?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, I think it -- it means that the statement in the report should not be taken -- given literal effect to it in any way that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did it refer to it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: What's that?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did it refer to it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, there's no question that 10 (b) -- that the report did refer to the rider.
But --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean, did the -- this last one you're talking about now, did it refer to the report on 10 (b)?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It did not refer to the report.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did it say anything inconsistent with it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, it certainly said the statement that it has made is inconsistent with the interpretation of 10 (b) that the petitioners are urging here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it inconsistent with the interpretation that was shown should be made by that report?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I don't think that the report indicates what interpretation should be made.
It merely says that they're imposing a statute of limitations and that makes the rider unnecessary.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I -- I'm a little confused.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I think you can clear me out.
A few times in Mr. Dunau's brief, he said also, the House Report No. 105 and, I gather, that report dated April 17, 1947.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, it refers to the current appropriations within the three-month period.
The rider to the then current appropriations bill to which the Senate Report referred has this provision which has been in existence for three months or longer without complaint.
I understood you to say that at the time this report was written, the rider had been watered down.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what rider are you referring?

It can't be the rider that the Senate Report was referring to because I gather that Mr. Dunau wants me to believe, wants me to assume that the rider referred to in this Report No. 105 is the one he sets forth on page 36, and that isn't any watering down.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, it is watered down to this extent.
It is watered down to the extent that it exempted contracts with company-dominated unions because that was put in 1945 and also, renewals of existing contracts.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does that mean -- was that true of the rider of which -- which the next record given on page 36 of his brief?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I believe it isn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it doesn't say anything about this company.
It doesn't give any indication that there was anything there except for these quotes.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, the -- it is Your Honor.
The “provided further,” that's down at the bottom of 36 and up at the top, “provided further that these limitations shall not apply to agreements”.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it is borne in violation.
(Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The report says that (Inaudible) is removed.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: In the first clause there where it says “no part of the funds appropriated shall be used in connection with a complaint case arriving over an agreement -- an agreement or a renewal thereof”.
Now, the Board's explanation of that clause “or a renewal thereof” is given in its report which is on pages 42 and 43 of Mr. Dunau's -- on page 48, I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: attorney
turn.label: Mr. Attorney
turn.text: I think it's 48.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Oh, it's --

turn.speaker: attorney
turn.label: Mr. Attorney
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: -- on page 44, Footnote 12, and that's borne out by the Comptroller General's explanation of this.
Item 2 in the footnote there, under the 1945 amendment, in contrast to the 1944 limitations, the renewal of an agreement --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where are you reading from?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I'm reading from the footnote on page 44 of Mr. Dunau's brief.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: 44, all right.
All right now --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Under Number 2 there on the footnote.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Under the 1945 amendment in contrast to the 1944 limitation, the renewal of an agreement, even though by virtue of the operation of an automatic renewal clause, starts anew a running of the three-month period during which a charge attacking the agreement may be filed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, is that --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Then, on top of -- of those two things, you have added the majority union exception that I mentioned, which it is true, was passed after the Senate Report was issued but nevertheless, was enacted by the very same Congress which enacted 10 (b).

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you regard the valid -- the -- the 1945 contract year as a renewal -- the second contract, the 1950 (Inaudible) I beg your pardon.
Do you regard that as a renewal within the term of the rider?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think it could be, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if it was a rider, the rider wasn't applicable to testify, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It wasn't applicable in 1955.
It -- it stopped --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: What is that?
No, no, it -- it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's nothing but the 10 (b) though.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct, but I'm -- I'm merely saying that if you're going to interpret 10 (b), precisely what the scope that the rider would have had, by the time 10 (b) came around, the rider was watered down to such an extent that it would not have precluded the Board from reaching the kind of a contract that you had in this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If you are to get -- if we are to get illumination from the reference to the rider in the Senate Report, the illumination must be from the totality of the rider and not a part of it.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, as I understand it, you -- what you're saying is watered down.
The chief thing they did was to say that company unions couldn't take advantage of this as it give them the repose, is that it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is one of the things that they said, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You're drawing from that conclusion that --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- could be entirely construed --

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- as to those that are not company unions?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: No, I said they did two other things.
They also exempted renewals of an existing contract and finally, in 1948, they exempted the contracts with minority unions.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean exempted renewals authorizing an attack on the renewal from the date it was renewed.
That's what you mean, isn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's this case?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, was this -- when was this -- when was this contract renewed?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It was renewed in August of 1955.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When was it made?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: It was made in August of 1954.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it doesn't come then within the time, the six months, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: The charges were filed with -- in -- in June of -- in August of 1955.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There would be no -- he would have no case here, would he, if he was claiming -- if you were claiming that unfair treatment of contracts dated from the time the renewal of contract was renewed?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It was within six months of that, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Yes, but you would still have to prove the illegality in the renewal from the -- from the past elapsed --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, we would have -- so that you'd have no repose then.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: You'd have no repose because they were continuing the contract, and the point I'm making is that you wouldn't have had a repose under the rider either.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could you -- do you have enough evidence here to justify a holding is an unfair trade practice considering this only as the renewal of the contract?
Has that been decided?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: I think that we have the same -- we would have to rely on the same evidence that we rely on for holding that the maintenance of the old contract and the renewal of the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, you mean you -- you couldn't prove that they had -- didn't have a majority when they made the renewal of contracts, is that it?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: You couldn't prove it without regard to how the majority was obtained to begin with.
It was a coerced majority at the outset.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: And that momentum continued throughout the period because there was nothing done to dissipate the momentum.
It was built up by the -- by the original coercion, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did you try to prove here that there wasn't a majority when they renewed it?
They didn't represent the majority?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, you couldn't do that because the check-off was operating and every employee who --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It has been operating for about 12 months.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, but the question is whether that check-off was properly entitled to operate or not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And as a matter of substantive law, the fact that they've been operating 10 months wouldn't make any difference in the orders in which this Court had sustained, telling the employer to take affirmative measures to undo what he had properly -- illegally done.

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct.
That is the holding of the Franks Brothers case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
That's what this Court has decided.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is this based on the fact that they've disobeyed an order or is it based on the fact that they made an illegal contract and then renewed an illegal contract?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: Well, it is not based on an order of this Court but the principle of the cases that Mr. Justice Frankfurter is referring to is that once the employer has engaged in a course of illegal conduct which has had the effect of dissipating the -- the Union's majority, unless there is some affirmative action to remedy that, it cannot, and the Board is justified in -- in so holding, you cannot create --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That was defined in cases where there were no statutes of limitations involved, was it not?

turn.speaker: norton_j_come
turn.label: Mr. Norton J. Come
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, but the -- but the principle, we submit, is the -- is the same here.
My time has expired.
I -- I just want to indicate that the Board's position on the reimbursement point, we believe, is fully set forth in our brief.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Unless there aren't any questions, I have nothing further.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I would like to ask this one question.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose this rider in effect (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: It would have barred this charge because certainly, with respect to the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As I understand it, the charge was by (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Another charge was filed with (Inaudible) contemporaneously, I gather, the renewal agreement.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Well, the -- actually, no.
The second charge -- I believe the second agreement was entered into after the second charge was filed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: After the second.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They were both filed on August (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: One charge was filed in June.
The second charge was filed in August.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And in some other day in August, the renewal (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: That is correct, sir, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, under the renewal or rather under the rider, the Board interpreted that in a footnote.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, that renewal gave (Inaudible) attacked three months after the respective date.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why do you say it's not under the defense?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: We -- we can divide it into two parts.
The Board made one finding, namely, that maintenance of the first agreement into a -- in effect, constitute a violation of the Act.
That could certainly not have been litigated under the rider because it -- the charge came more than three months after that agreement.

Now, it seems to me that when the rider said a renewal can be -- a renewal agreement can be attacked within three months, it said, “Yes, from three months on August 31st, 1955, you can attack that agreement,” but I do not think it said at the same time that if your evidence necessary to attack that second agreement has to go back to the evidence which would open the first agreement, and you were barred from opening the first agreement, that the rider would not have protected both the first and the second, otherwise, on the renewal, you would have reopened what have been closed by the first --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think that attacks the matter that as a matter of evidence, if it's a matter of substantive law, the renewal revives or continues the original illegality that you can't, as a matter of evidence, resort to -- to that which substantively is barred.
In other words, if the statute of limitations may bar a cause of action but it doesn't bar other evidence.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: It does not bar evidence, Your Honor, except if you're going to get any effect either to the riders or to Section 10 (b).
It must bar the substantive unfair labor practice which precedes, by more than six months, the charge, else, you have never barred the unfair labor practice.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You can't bring it back to anywhere we've been --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) under 10 (b) (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: I think you're -- that is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The problem is different from the rider.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: The pro -- yes, sir, it is different because under the rider, there is no possible claim that you there -- under the rider, you have to file your charge within three months of the inception of the agreement.
It says so in so many words.

Now, our argument is, if under the rider you have to file your charge within three months of the agreement, we cannot understand an interpretation of Section 10 (b) which replaces the rider which says that you do not measure the limitations from the inception of the agreement but from -- well, you don't measure it from anything because it continue -- it never runs.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you say -- and you say I can't read the riders to say that the renewal sustained and continues in light of the original agreement and therefore, the effective -- the -- the base point for -- as a matter of time, is the renewal.
They're not the original that which is renewed.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: What we draw from the riders and all we draw from the riders is that when Congress was dealing with this explicit situation of an agreement valid on its face but illegal because it was entered into with a minority union, it started its limitations period running from the date the execution of the agreement -- from the date of the execution of the agreement and the Board always understood, even after the 1945 rider was enacted which had the renewal language in it.
It said in its annual reports, “We cannot attack an agreement once the three months has expired even with a union which did not represent the majority when the agreement was executed."
That's what we draw from the riders.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) say it's true at all that the 1948 rider can provide the security on (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: The 1948 rider is a totally different situation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was being passed in those recent times.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Yes, sir, but it was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did they incorporate it in the committee report?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.text: No?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau

If -- we'd have a wholly different --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That -- that rider, by its very terms, conserve to (Inaudible) or make no limitations.

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: The 1948 rider was enacted subsequent to Section 10 (b).
It's a meaningless rider the way it's written because you don't need a rider to protect an agreement entered into with a majority union.
And if you read the rider -- the 1948 rider literally, that's all you get out of it.
You get nothing from it.

It seems to us that the true explanation of the 1948 rider is that this whole limitations problem had already been settled by Section 10 (b) and if a couple of Senators or Congressmen wanted to enact the limitations rider having a different policy than Section 10 (b), nobody in Congress was interested in opposing it because the problem had already been settled in 10 (b).

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Dunau, is the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Can I still ask him a question?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is it of any significance to your case that the contract was made in August 1954?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Well, it's significant in that, as a date, it is more than six months preceding the filing of the charge.
That's the only significance I draw from August 1954, if I understand the question.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Do you think then you are -- aside from that fact, just as well off as though there were no contract at all?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: Well, probably not.

If there were no contract at all, the Board would have a heck of a lot of more problems by way of proof, but I don't see that -- that -- analytically, it makes a difference whether the contract which reports the relationship is reduced to writing or whether the relationship is a practice which is unrecorded in writing.

Now, what we always get back to, and this is the finding of the Board from which, it seems to me, there is no escape of where we must begin, this is a product contract used defensively, all kinds of -- of verbalisms have been resorted to.
The finding is explicit.
The finding is that at the time the company and the IAM executed the August 1954 agreement, the Unions did not represent the majority of the employees covered by the agreement but that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What page is that?

turn.speaker: bernard_dunau
turn.label: Mr. Bernard Dunau
turn.text: I am reading from page 10 of my brief, Your Honor, which cites the Board's relevant finding on this subject.
This is the finding, that on August 10, 1954, the company and the Union entered into an agreement and the Union didn't have a majority.
And then, we have the crucial finding of the substantive violations.

It follows, therefore, and we find that the company violated Section 8 (a) (1), (2) and (3) and the Unions 8 (b) (1) (a) and (2) by maintaining in effect the 1954 agreement and by executing and maintaining in effect the 1955 agreement, both of which, contained unlawful union security clauses.
But what the Board was doing was finding that the agreements constituted unfair labor practices, the maintenance in effect and the execution and maintenance of the second agreement.
Not defensively, they weren't finding unfair labor practice upon any other basis.
And I might just add this, Your Honors, the union security provision of this agreement is, in this case, a red herring.
Nothing turns upon the fact that there is a union shop provision in this agreement.
We have the cases cited on our brief.
Without a union shop agreement, you get exactly the same violation of Section 8 (a) (1) and (2).
As the Board has stressed, all that the union shop provision does is to aggravate the violation.
It accents it.
But the violation exists with or without the union shop provision.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
